Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Fran was one of the deadliest tropical cyclones in the history of Cape Verde. The sixth named storm and eleventh tropical cyclone of the 1984 Atlantic hurricane season, Fran developed from a tropical wave near Cape Verde on September 15.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 29 people were killed, though some sources claim there were as many as 32 fatalities.

Total_Death_Per_Country.Death_with_annotation: At least 29 people were killed, though some sources claim there were as many as 32 fatalities.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: At least 29 people were killed, though some sources claim there were as many as 32 fatalities.

Total_Summary_Insured_Damage.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: Overall, the storm caused at least $2.84 million (1984 USD) in damage.

Total_Insured_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: Overall, the storm caused at least $2.84 million (1984 USD) in damage.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Insured_Da.Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_annotatio: On Santo Antão, São Nicolau, and Santiago, agriculture also suffered losses, totaling to $1.84 million (1984 USD).
The hydraulic infrastructure on Santo Antão, Santiago, São Nicolau, São Vicente, Fogo, and Maio was destroyed and cost about $1 million (1984 USD) to repair.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: Light winds were reported in Cape Verde; some weather stations recorded winds of 35 miles per hour (56 km/h). As a result, wind damage was minimal.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: While passing southeast of Cape Verde, Fran dropped torrential rainfall on the islands, which caused significant flooding.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: While passing southeast of Cape Verde, Fran dropped torrential rainfall on the islands, which caused significant flooding.
